Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: HIGH-SPEED AFM IMAGING OF DYNAMICS ON BIOPOLYMERS THROUGH NON-RASTER SCANNING
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award by the Instrument Development for Biological Research (IDBR) program in the Division of Biological Infrastructure (BIO Directorate) is co-funded by the Particulate and Multiphase Processes (PMP) program in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (CBET, Engineering Directorate).

Non Technical Abstract
The primary aim of this project is to create a novel high-speed atomic force microscope (AFM) imaging system with frame rates of on the order of 100 frames/second. While the creation of this instrument may have a significant impact on a broad range of application areas, the primary target is the study of biomolecular processes. The extremely fast frame rate and long range will allow for the direct visualization of dynamic process that previously could be studied at best only through indirect means. The interdisciplinary nature of the project provides excellent opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate student training as well as outreach to middle- and high-school age students through summer programs on nano- and biotechnology.

Technical Abstract
The speed gains of the instrument will be achieved in two ways. The first way is to replace the standard raster-scan of AFM with a feedback algorithm that steers the tip to stay in the region of interest. This will reduce imaging time by reducing the amount of scanning to be done, with the tradeoff that the sample to be imaged must have an underlying string-like structure such as is found in biopolymers. The second way is to create dual-stage scanning systems that will allow the non-raster scanning to be performed at ultra-fast speeds. A prototype system will be built and demonstrated on a variety of standard samples before being deployed to study the dynamics of the molecular motor myosin V. The instrument and underlying techniques will be disseminated through journal publication and conference publication and through collaboration with an existing AFM company to integrate the techniques in their next generation devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This IDBR project was a collaboration between researchers at Boston University and the University of Utah with the aim of developing a high-speed atomic force microscope suitable for imaging dynamics on biopolymers (such as DNA, actin, and microtubules) with frame rates at least an order of magnitude faster than currently achievable. The project involved two main thrusts. At Boston University, the primary goal was to create algorithms for using the data coming from the instrument in real time to guide the data acquisition process to regions of interest rather than simply generating an image of a region independent of the details of the sample. Under this approach, an image frame is a thin slice of the area directly surrounding the biopolymer, leading to significant reductions in imaging time simply by reducing the number of measurements needed to produce a high quality image. Using an existing commercial microscope, this approach was implemented and demonstrated to produce better than an order magnitude reduction in imaging time.

At the University of Utah, the primary goal was to create a high-speed dual-stage scanner for scanning probe microscopy systems. Such a system can overcome the standard tradeoff between scan range and scan speed by combining a long range, though relatively slow, actuator with a short range but very fast actuator. This dual-stage design concept combines a novel flexure-based mechanical amplifier for the lateral motion and a compact three-axis shear piezoactuator for the secondary high-speed stage, resulting in high-performance nanopositioning in three axes.  To further enhance the performance of the dual-stage system, an advanced feedback control system that incorporates state and disturbance estimation, master-slave architecture, sliding mode control, and nonlinear hysteresis inversion was developed and tested for AFM imaging.

Beyond the technical achievements, this project involved a total of five doctoral students (three at Boston University and two at the University of Utah), four master’s students (three at Boston University and one at the University of Utah), and five undergraduate students (three at Boston University and two at the University of Utah). Students at all levels received training in imaging systems with nanometer scale features, in control engineering, in algorithm implementation, in advanced mechanical design, in compliant mechanisms, and in precision mechatronics.
